captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

MATT FARAH: "Tuned"
is officially
back with this clap.
I know you've missed us.

Now, if you were with us when we
ended last season, we had a

focus on balance,
with the Turner
Motorsports M3 race car.

Now while we will be bringing
you ridiculously over-powered

vehicles this season, I wanted
to start with a car that damn

near every single one of you
emailed me and said, Matt, you

need to drive a turbocharged
Scion FR-S.

I love the FR-S. And that's why
I was so excited when the

guys from team VCMC
in Canadia--
that's Vancouver, Canada--

called me and said, Matt,
wherever you want me to bring
this car, I will bring it.

So they have driven 22 hours to
Chuckwalla, here in, well,

damn near the middle
of nowhere.

We had to do what we had to do,
which is why we're sharing

a track day with a bunch
of LeMons race cars.
This should be fun, too.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[CAR ENGINE]
MATT FARAH: Here we go.

Turobcharged FR-S track car, on
track, with a whole bunch
of $500 race cars.

Now I have about six laps total
of Chuckwalla Valley

raceway, so still trying to
figure out where I'm going a
little bit.

Fun track, way out in the middle
of the desert, very
fast, a lot of sweepers.

Here's what I can tell
you about this car.

It was built in Canada by VCMC
and Shift Autosport for

Canada's Scion Turner
Challenge.

You may have seen some
of those cars at
SEMA, the US versions.

And in case you can't see the
smile on my face right now, it
is very nice.

They have taken a stock FR-S
and turned it into the

ultimate weekend at
the track car.
It sounds great.

It's got a full-blown
motorsports turbo kit on it,

feeding the 2 liter Boxer engine
9 pounds of boost,

which provides 320
horsepower at the
wheels, in current trip.

It's a stock bottom end, so they
didn't want to run too

much boost and risk
blowing it up.

Then they gutted the interior,
so this car is down to 2,400
pounds right now.

They replaced the suspension
with KW Variant 3 coilovers,
full polyurethane bushings.

And then they put 17 by 9 wheels
on it, super sticky
Hoosier tires.

I'm going to pass
this '84 Supra.

With those square stands up
front that it's got, it's got

245s all round, completely
square, the
turning is really amazing.

Very direct, amazing
steering wheel.

They put a bushing in the
shifter to give it a little
crisper feel.

I like that they haven't
ruined that.

And then they put a light
flywheel assembly, so it revs
up a little quicker.

The original flywheel
is pretty heavy.

What I really like about this
car is that they've managed to
keep the FR-S's character.
They haven't ruined it.

When you're building a car like
this, it would be very

easy to ruin it, and they
have not done that.

Everything I know
about driving a
stock FR-S, still here.

It's just better at everything
it does.

When building a Tuner car,
especially one for the track,

the tendency is to go overboard
in a mishmash of

assorted aftermarket parts,
without a cohesive theme,

thereby ending up with a car
that may be fast but drives

completely unlike the car you
started with and, often cases,
much worse.
Here, they haven't done that.

Most importantly, it feels like
a complete package, with
no single element overshadowing
the rest of the build.

RICHARD BASFORD: Our goal was
building a car that was

completely versatile for the
enthusiast or the grassroots
motorsports guy.

So he can use it on a daily
basis, but mainly it goes out

on the weekend and wins and does
really well and drives
fast and is easy to use.

The overall grip level has been
so high, as soon as we

started to delve in to
suspension and upgrading to

the different tires
and so forth.

But it's just been a super
easy car to work on.

Every single modification we
do just makes it faster.

So it's not like, say, an
S-2000, where you have to do

the right thing perfectly
just to get it fast.

Because everything we throw at
it just makes it better.

The weakest link that we found
from the FR-S from factory was
definitely the power.

That's something we addressed
with our last upgrade, which

is the turbo system that
you're driving
today from Full Blown.

When you're trying to build a
balanced race car, you want

every piece of it
to be strong.

And that's really where
we've focused lately.
[CAR ENGINES]
MATT FARAH: [INAUDIBLE]
are sticking.

The suspension is doing
it's thing.

I can feel everything that's
going on through
the steering wheel.

I love that about the FR-S.
This one, they have not
changed that.

This is a fan-frigging-tastic
track car.
It's brilliant to drive.

Everyone in the paddock
loves it.

It's not crazy expensive
to build.
I mean, the car's $25,000.

They said they've got about
another $20,000 into it.
So $45,000 isn't cheap.

But we're talking about a track
car and a fast one, so
pretty reasonable.
I like the brakes a lot.

The rear rotors are still stock,
but the front rotors
are AP Racing.

And they really do a great job
of bringing this thing down.

Also got some aerodynamic
things going on.

We got the big APR wing in the
back, diffuser up front.

I'm not sure how much of it is
due to the suspension and how

much is due to the aero,
but it feels
really, really planted.

It doesn't want to
tear my face off.

And as we learned in the last
season of "Tuned," at the end,
the importance of balance.

And this car definitely
is balanced.

Not really a complaint, just
a little observation.

The throttle is kind of
like an on-off switch.

So like any other race car, it's
much happier being flat

or off than it is being
somewhere in the middle.
It's getting a little hot.

I think I might have
to go to the pits.

The problem with this car
is that it gets hot.

I don't think they've fully
dialed in the cooling system.

They did say I'm the first
person to ever
track test this car.

If this super Scion
suffers from one
issue, it's heat stroke--

more specifically, a tendency
to overheat after a few laps
on the track.

This is a common theme among
cars on "Tuned." As many

builds are literally finished
the night before our shoot,

others value our testing
as important in
their development process.

In this case, it was
a bit of both.

And we learned that the FR-S,
when turbocharged, needs some

extra airflow by opening
up the front air dam.

RICHARD BASFORD: So with Matt
driving the car today, one

thing that we definitely learned
was we've got a bit of
a heat issue.

So we're going to have to open
up the front compartment a
little bit.

We're going to have to look into
ducting away some of the

turbo heat and just
keep improving.

I mean that's one of the things
about this challenge is
that it's 18 months long.

We're not going to get it
right the first time.

It's always going to be
improving, always looking to

make the car faster
and better.

The turbo just went in to get
it here for you today.

Love it or hate it, the Scion
FR-S is bound to become the
next generation of spec racer.
It's roomier than a Miata.

The aftermarket for
it is expanding
unbelievably quickly.

And when prepped for the track,
its handling limits are

absurdly high, and power
is easy to come by.

Furthermore, as we are now
officially into our third

season, the VCMC Turbo FR-S
reminds us that, throughout

this season, we must always
keep balance in mind.
[MUSIC]
[CAR ENGINE]
[LOUD WIND]

title: The 350 HP VCMC Turbo Scion FR-S - /TUNED

comments.text:
Just buy an RX-8 and suddenly everything the FRS does was just improved. 
Not speaking by opinion, but on paper.﻿
comments.author: Braden Asper

comments.text:
My rx8 lasted over 100 miles b4 I sold it. I beat on it every day. 4krpm 
clutch drops, power shifting, reving to 9.5krpm every day. Over 70k miles 
of tourture. It wasn't all abuse but the clutch petal bracket and 
transmission were the weak link... of course u can't boost them reliably 
which Is why I got the frs, but my rx8 on 245s eats my frs on 215s, though 
the frs is much more predictable when ur over the limit.
comments.author: Thomas Threatt

comments.text:
thats hilarious, im a huge RX fanboy but this is so untrue 

you know what a BRZ/FRS does better than a RX8? survive. 

rotaries are infamous for crapping out after/around 100k miles (which is 
pathetic) if that wasn't bad enough they are one of the most expensive 
rebuilds you can get due to being the only car (other than its 
predecessors) that have a rotary in North America
comments.author: Mike Zita

comments.text:
Rotaries are a lot less reliable if you don't take care of it like a baby. 
An FRS/BRZ/GT-86 is a reliable car that needs an oil  change every 4000 
miles and minimal work. If you are a rotary fan, you're a rotary fan and 
will do what you gotta do to have one, but as for a daily driver an RX-8 
isn't wise, a brz/frs/gt-86 is a reliable daily driver that won't have many 
issues. I wouldn't consider an RX-8 a better car in those senses.
comments.author: Connor Keegan

comments.text:
+Thomas Threatt
 rotarys burn oil way to much. just put a turbo on it and be happy with a 
new car.
comments.author: MechHead Naga GMG

comments.text: I went from rx8 to frs and ur right, almost.

comments.text: Is it just me or does Matt seem huge in his car.﻿
comments.author: Josh Tongate

comments.text:
Which 'full blown motorsports' turbo trim is used on this car? The t3 50, 
t3 57, or one of the larger g series turbos?﻿
comments.author: SUCKINAWNCLITS

comments.text:
Poor man's tuning car? Get a used bmw 335i under $25k. With simple chip 
tune for about $400, you will get about 350-380. $45-50k tuned brz? i'd 
rather get a good used v8 m3 and drift all day long with that NA 400HP.﻿
comments.author: Stig Bimm

comments.text:
Dont get me wrong. I am open to any cars as long as cost effective and good 
to have fun. Great car the AE86 is, no doubt. But doing a turbo mod on any 
factory NA engine seems a bit too much. Supercharger mod seems to be more 
feasible though. Yes, I do love bmw, but not all of the line ups. I just 
happen to own one of them, and been having fun a lot for the past 3 years 
with a very frugal budget to raise it's horsepower and tq by about 50% over 
stock believe it or not. Yeah, you can call me a fan boy...lol. I really do 
love this n54 engine. You should give it a try. Maint isn't that bad. I 
haven't spent anything for maint for outsourcing. I've done everything 
pretty much myself at home except for the differential swap. Great car and 
built tough for sure.
comments.author: Stig Bimm

comments.text: Just a BMW fan boy.. Smh. I guess bmws are just the best track cars ever
comments.author: Thomas Threatt

comments.text:
S65 4.0 V8 is extremely reliable. I'd guess modding a car that's really not 
meant to be like the supercharged FRS wouldn't be that much reliable at 
all. Factory tuned I believe is still the best no matter how much expert a 
tuning shop can be. Amount of resources and numbers of brains, you can 
never match the factory. In the end, you go for what you want.
comments.author: Stig Bimm

comments.text:
You forget that yes you might be able to pay a used e92 m3 or e46, but the 
main thing is maintenance. Bmw is ridiculously expensive, and if you were 
to use it for track purposes, a lot of maintenance needs to be done, 
especially if you get in any minor - major accident. I have a BRZ and i 
have already needed to replace parts and they cost only about a fraction of 
the price of my Moms X5. Unless you have a good amount of money to back up 
your car an FRS/BRZ/GT86 is well worth the money imo. You dont need to pay 
another 20k for a fact track car, all you need is slight performance 
upgrades, and it is already a fun track car.
comments.author: charlesandjulien

comments.text:
clutch is expensive. my tuned 335i with roughly 400hp/430tq is already 
having a slipping issue, bc it wasnt factory built for that kinda power. 
again its all about balance/sweet spot. just bc its lighter or power to wt 
ratio is higher doesnt mean its better per gtr's chief engineer. that sweet 
spot is very hard to find and those $70k or higher cars right out of 
factories are no joke. like i said you go with your pref and budget, but if 
you purely go for a great track toy, id choose something else other than 
this souped up frs regardless of its warranty(which is going to be voided 
if any engine mods r detected).
comments.author: Stig Bimm

comments.text:
+Based Dean +Stig P Don't forget a clutch to support the engine power, an 
STI tranny otherwise you will be breaking the FR-s one, CPU for STI, this 
is just a few details that would take the price of the swap make you feel 
STUPID!  A few years back M3, AUDI or even VW R32 with a few mods will make 
you smile in the track. FRS is just a toy.
comments.author: vwvr6t

comments.text:
+Stig P  why get used when you can get brand new 2014 FR-S/BRZ for 26k and 
swap out that 200HP FA20 Subi engine for a 325hp stock LS1 motor for no 
more then $3,500 used from a wrecked Camaro/Firebird/Corvette thats bout 
29.5k and with LTHs and good full exhaust and dyno tune your LS1 can be at 
350hp and 400hp at the wheels ez with a T-56(6 speed). Plus as you can hear 
from the guy driving the FRS/BRZ it handles better then 60k+ cars like 911 
turbo and M5. its the perfect Entry level sports car STOCK. even with the 
200hp stock it wieghs 2,700lbs they did a stage 1 weight reduction which 
dropped it 300lbs. just think if you did a full on wieght reduction 
dropping the car to 2,000 lbs that stock 200hp will seem alot faster lol 
power to weight ratio always wins bro.
comments.author: Based Dean

comments.text:
true. but lighter doesnt always mean better. i still prefer factory tune 
like gtr or m3 due to their enormous amt of resource to put everything 
together. in the end its your pref.
comments.author: Stig Bimm

comments.text: this frs is going to be significantly lighter though.

comments.text:
Okay now I'm kinda blown away at the difference in sound between Crawford 
BRZ vs VCMC FR-S. Both turbo'd but both amazing sounds. What is better

comments.text:

comments.author: BigBerg95

comments.text:
Not only does Mr. Crawford make great engines he's also a great guy too! We

comments.author: Richard Basford

comments.text:
Oh I know that Crawford is like a platter of goodness! And you got Crawford

My Dad had a new 91' Toyota MR2 turbo that was 0-60 in 5.9 seconds. I use 
to sneak that thing out all the time. I had it up to 145 mph one morning. 
The car really fluttered bad though when the t-tops were off and you went 
over 100. Where is ford and chevy on this? They should be ashamed not to 
have a dog in this race.
